articles.headline: The Carbon Calculus
articles.snippet: A proposal in Congress to put a price tag on greenhouse-gas emissions could overturn the economics of energy.
articles.abstract: A proposal in Congress to put a price tag on greenhouse-gas emissions could overturn the economics of energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A CHANGE is in the works that could go a long way toward making alternative energy less alternative, and more attractive to consumers and businesses.

articles.headline: For Suppliers, the Pressure Is On
articles.snippet: Call it Phase 3 of the greening of corporate America. Companies are looking at their supply chain as the next frontier for combating climate change.
articles.abstract: Call it Phase 3 of the greening of corporate America. Companies are looking at their supply chain as the next frontier for combating climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOME DEPOT did not sell organic roses this past Mother’s Day. Why? There were no cheap local ones available. And the amount of carbon that would have been emitted by shipping cheap ones from Venezuela seemed to eclipse any environmental benefit of avoiding pesticides and such.

articles.headline: Bonuses Likely to Shrink for Many on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Wall Street bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, making them the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market.
articles.abstract: Wall Street bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, making them the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street bonuses may be the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market. Over all, bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, according to compensation experts and Wall Street executives.

articles.headline: For Citigroup’s New Head, Focus Is Subprime Tangle
articles.snippet: Robert E. Rubin, who was named Citigroup’s chairman after the departure of Charles O. Prince III, has moved quickly to deal with the turmoil that has engulfed the banking giant.
articles.abstract: Robert E. Rubin, who was named Citigroup’s chairman after the departure of Charles O. Prince III, has moved quickly to deal with the turmoil that has engulfed the banking giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until Sunday, Robert E. Rubin collected over $18 million a year as Wall Street’s ultimate hands-off executive. On Monday, he had to roll up his sleeves.

articles.headline: Within the Fed, Resistance to Further Rate Cuts
articles.snippet: In an blunt interview, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said he would not back more rate cuts unless the economy slowed further than current estimates.
articles.abstract: In an blunt interview, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said he would not back more rate cuts unless the economy slowed further than current estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — Even if the economy slows sharply in the final quarter of this year, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are opposed to cutting rates again at their next meeting, in December.

articles.headline: Pakistani Lawyers Angered as Hope for Change Faded
articles.snippet: Disappointment turned to fury after Gen. Pervez Musharraf scrapped the Supreme Court and the Constitution.
articles.abstract: Disappointment turned to fury after Gen. Pervez Musharraf scrapped the Supreme Court and the Constitution.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 6 — Behind the public rage of Pakistan’s lawyers, who protested for a second day on Tuesday, lies a long-smoldering resentment toward the country’s military president, who at first held out promise for educated, politically moderate Pakistanis, but steadily squandered their support.

articles.headline: When Trust in an Expert Is Unwise
articles.snippet: A study of car mechanics comes to a depressing conclusion about situations where the expert who diagnoses a problem is the one who will be paid to fix it.
articles.abstract: A study of car mechanics comes to a depressing conclusion about situations where the expert who diagnoses a problem is the one who will be paid to fix it.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, an economics graduate student named Henry Schneider drove his dad’s old Subaru station wagon up to Montreal. He had heard about a Canadian consumer interest group that had done undercover investigations of auto-repair shops, and he wanted to try a more academic version of its experiment.

articles.headline: Little-Known Entrepreneurs Putting China Near Top of Billionaires’ List
articles.snippet: A year ago, there were 15 billionaires in China. Now, there are more than 100, according to the widely watched Hurun Report.
articles.abstract: A year ago, there were 15 billionaires in China. Now, there are more than 100, according to the widely watched Hurun Report.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Nov. 6 — The United States has more billionaires than any other country: 415 by the last count of Forbes magazine.

articles.headline: Deadly Fires Expose Disorder in Putin’s Russia
articles.snippet: Respect for law, safety and public health still lag far behind the Kremlin’s restored sense of self.
articles.abstract: Respect for law, safety and public health still lag far behind the Kremlin’s restored sense of self.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Nov. 6 — Sergei Babayan was trapped. Minutes before, wisps of smoke had begun flowing through cracks in his classroom door at the private Moscow Institute of Government and Corporate Management.

articles.headline: High-Priced Oil Adds Volatility to Power Scramble
articles.snippet: The prospect of triple-digit oil prices has redrawn the economic and political map of the world.
articles.abstract: The prospect of triple-digit oil prices has redrawn the economic and political map of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the price of oil surges toward a symbolic milestone of $100 a barrel — hitting $96.70 yesterday — it is creating new winners and losers across the globe.

articles.headline: Your Ad Here: Web Surprise Hits ’08 Race
articles.snippet: Campaigns venturing into the unruly territory of Web advertising risk losing what they crave most: control.
articles.abstract: Campaigns venturing into the unruly territory of Web advertising risk losing what they crave most: control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — Visitors to Gay.com can sign up to find the perfect dating partner, advice on sex and how-to articles on same-sex marriage and parenting.
